unnormalised: Someone asked about understanding online transactions better? Here's a bit about it from my experience. Basically, when you buy something online, like from Flipkart or Amazon, there are a lot of numbers involved. You'll see prices like Rs. 499 for a t-shirt or Rs. 12,999 for a mobile. These prices often include GST, which might be shown separately, say at 18% for certain items.

unnormalised: Then, when you pay, you might use UPI, credit card, or net banking. Each transaction has a unique transaction ID, something like TXN20240715ABC123. If you use a wallet like Paytm, you might have a balance of Rs. 5000. There can also be convenience fees charged, maybe around Rs. 20-50 depending on the platform and payment method.

unnormalised: Discounts and cashback offers also play a big role. You might see a "Flat 10% off" or "₹200 cashback on orders above ₹2000". Keep an eye out for these deals! Also, remember that many e-commerce sites use star ratings like 4.5/5 to give you an idea of other customers' experiences with that seller.
